title: Business Live: Pound gives up gains - BBC News
summary: pound hits six-month high against euro .
but it 's now fallen to €1.14 and $ 1.34 .
us firms add 228,000 jobs but wages stall .
bitcoin falls to $ 15,000 after bumpy ride .
ba to close defined benefit pensions .

documents.title: good night
text: that 's all for this evening and this week - thanks very much for reading .
do join us on monday when we 'll be back from 06:00am .
here 's a quick recap of the main developments today :

documents.title: wall street finishes on a high note
text: the dow jones index ended the week up around 0.49 % , or 117.68 points , to 24,329.16
the s & p 500 closed up 0.55 % to 2,651.50 , a rise of 14.52 points .
the nasdaq also ended on a high , at 6,840.08 , up 0.340 % or 27.24 points for the session .

documents.title: rates to rise under powell ?
text: the markets overwhelmingly expect the us federal reserve to raise interest rates at a meeting next week .
and one analyst says the next hike is likely to come when jerome powell takes over from janet yellen as chair of the central bank early next year .

`` by the time the fed meets in march , we expect to see sub-4 % unemployment , accompanied by a clear uptick in wages and no softening in the payroll trend , '' says ian shepherdson , chief economist at pantheon macroeconomics .
`` we think mr. powell 's first meeting will bring a rate hike . ''

mr powell , a multi-millionaire lawyer-turned-investment banker , still needs official approval from congresss , although he took a step closer this week when he was backed by a senate banking committee .

documents.title: bitcoin steadies after rollercoaster ride
text: the chart above shows the wild day of trading for bitcoin - in which it 's crossed $ 17,000 but also dropped $ 3,000 in a matter of hours .
since then the digital currency has steadied a bit , and is now hovering at around $ 15,000 .
bitcoin - which many see as a speculative investment rather than a currency - went through a similar hairy ride last night , as warnings of a bubble continue to mount .

documents.title: what 's new pussycat ?
text: tech tent - crypto kitties and russian votes on blockchain .
read the blog , grab the podcast !

documents.title: 'kicking the can down the road '
text: what are analysts saying about sterling falling back to levels seen before the brexit breakthrough ?
`` there 's a sense here that we 're just moving on to the next issue .
have we really done anything more than kicking the can down the road a little bit ? ''
said societe generale macro strategist kit juckes .
but it 's also `` just a december friday - no one 's going to go in and buy lots of pounds .
we 've had a decent run and nobody wants to enter the weekend with a lot of risk on the table '' .
rbc strategists said brexit negotiations aside , the economy remained in a fragile state .
figures from the ons this morning showed construction output unexpectedly fell by 1.7 % in october , although manufacturing performed better , rising by 0.1 % .

documents.title: us economy gets better and better ?
text: analysts at fitch ratings offer a rosy of the us economy in the new year .
in a report published friday , fitch says it expects us economic growth to accelerate to 2.5 % next year , after `` outperforming expectations '' in 2017 .
`` consumption is growing steadily , supported by improving labour markets , and global trade conditions have been supportive . ''
a report published friday said .
it says a package of tax cuts promised by republicans will provide a boost - and add to the debt .
but that 's not likely to knock the us from its position as the most highly indebted nation with its top aaa rating , given demand for the dollar , fitch adds .
`` it would take a significant shock to affect the us rating , '' the report says .

documents.title: watch : beware christmas knock-offs
text: watch : beware christmas knock-offs

documents.title: oil rallies
text: oil prices are up by more than 1 % on friday after sliding backwards for most of the week .
brent crude is nearly a cent higher at $ 63.10 a barrel on the back of rising chinese crude demand and threats of a strike in nigeria , africa 's largest oil exporter .
but prices are still on track for weekly losses amid concerns that rising us production could undermine the supply cuts masterminded by oil cartel opec .

documents.title: sterling slides further
text: the pound has now fallen back below €1.14 and $ 1.34 - the levels it was at before last night 's breakthrough in the brexit talks .
analysts said the pound remains volatile as traders try to weigh up the potential pitfalls in the next round of negotiations .
sterling is down 0.6 % against the dollar at $ 1.33950 , and has fallen 0.5 % against the euro to €1.13910 .

documents.title: brexit deal : how the night unfolded
text: a dramatic dawn breakthrough saw the prime minister secure a last minute deal to move brexit talks onto the next phase .
reports overnight - and then the confirmation this morning - saw the pound rise against the dollar and hit a six-month high against the euro , before easing back this afternoon .
a night of telephone diplomacy finished with theresa may and david davis heading to brussels , where they had this breakfast meeting with jean claude juncker and michel barnier .
you can read the full story of what happened here .

documents.title: this week 's ftse winners
text: it 's been a tricky week for the ftse 100 index , as it slumped to a 10-week low on thursday before an impressive rebound on friday meant it finished the week just below 7,400 points .
here were the companies which gained the most this week :

documents.title: business beastsin case you missed our a-z of animal-inspired business jargon
text: sharks , bear markets , narwhals & yak shaving - do you know the business beast abc ?
full guide here via @ twitterid

documents.title: who bought the $ 450m da vinci ?
text: it was one of the mysteries in a story that was already like a blockbuster novel .
the buyer of the salvator mundi painting , which sold for a record $ 450m last month , has now been revealed .
abu dhabi has confirmed it bought the world 's most expensive artwork for the state 's new louvre gallery .
the louvre abu dhabi museum - which opened earlier this month and cost an estimated £ 1bn to build - said it was looking forward to `` displaying the painting '' .
the 500-year-old artwork of christ is believed to be the work of leonardo da vinci .
in 1958 it was sold at auction in london for a mere £ 45 .
at the time it was generally reckoned to be the work of a follower of leonardo , but most scholars now believe it was by the renaissance master himself .

documents.title: ftse gains from pound pain
text: the uk 's 100 share index put on a spurt in afternoon trading to finish 1 % higher at 7,393.96 points .
the ftse 100 hit a 10-week low yesterday on the back of gains in the pound .
today it was the opposite story , with falls in sterling giving the index a boost .
many of the firms on the ftse 100 make their profits abroad .
when sterling falls , those overseas earnings are worth more when converted back into pounds .
`` the early positive momentum in sterling ran out of steam and then the pound turned negative - which propped up the ftse 100 , '' said david madden of cmc markets .

documents.title: apple fixes smart home flaw
text: it 's not what you want really if you have a `` smart home '' .
a bug in the latest version of apple 's mobile operating system could have let criminals unlock internet-connected doors or control their lights .
the tech giant says it has now fixed the security flaw in its homekit system that could have let unauthorised people control smart home gadgets .
it has disabled remote homekit access for shared users , as a temporary solution to the problem .
read more from the bbc tech team here .

documents.title: check-in ?
text: there 's another twist in the ongoing battle for control of uk hotel chain , millennium & copthorne hotels .

singaporean billionaire kwek leng beng 's investment vehicle has upped its offer for the company - which has seven hotels in london , including the millennium at chelsea fc 's stamford bridge stadium .
millennium & copthorne has agreed to the improved offer , which values it at about £ 2bn .
and investors seem to like the deal .
the ftse 250 company 's shares are almost 5.5 % higher in late trading in london to 612 pence - slightly less than the offer from kwek leng beng 's cdl group .
breaking : cdl has upped its offer for millennium & copthorne hotels from 552.5p a share to 620p including special divi .
it 's a final offer but will it be enough to win over minorities ?
not much alternative
it will probably be enough imho
cdl has hiked its bid for m & c to 620p a share , valuing the entire company at £ 2bn .
big improvement on previous 552.5p offer and it has declared it final .
independent directors have recommended it , story out on reuters now

documents.title: 'raise uk rates to stop overheating '
text: the uk economy grew at 0.5 % in the three months to november , according to the national institute of economic and social research ( niesr ) , following stronger manufacturing data for october .

economist amit kara says : `` if , as we expect , the economy continues to expand around this pace and inflation remains elevated , there is a case for the bank of england to gradually raise the policy rate to stop the economy from overheating . ''

documents.title: so , did 'soft brexit ' just win ?
text: here 's an extract from kamal 's blog on today 's first-round brexit agreement .
for the full article , click here .
if britain does become a `` third country '' - that is trading with the eu as other non-eu countries outside the single market and the customs union do - then border controls will be necessary .
and that open border will become very much more closed .
there is at least a partial way around this conundrum .
and it necessitates the comprehensive free trade deal the british government has said it wants .
and at least closely mirroring customs arrangements we presently adhere to as members of the eu 's customs union .
that equates for many with a `` soft brexit '' and is the trajectory many economists argue would be best for the uk economy .
author: Kamal Ahmed
Economics editor

text: donald trump has got his smartphone out again ( unless his lawyer has been given the password again ) .
wells fargo shares have shrugged it off - they 're up 0.8 % at $ 59.84 a share .

documents.title: pound braced for 'bumpy road '
text: sterling has slipped further from the six-month high it hit against the euro this morning when the uk and eu agreed a first-round deal .
the pound is now hovering just above €1.14 , having fallen 0.3 % against the euro .
against the dollar , sterling is trading 0.4 % lower at about $ 1.34 .
analysts said the markets were turning attention to the task ahead as the brexit talks turn to trade issues .
`` we could see more upside in the pound in the coming months but as it was before , the road ahead is bumpy and that will be reflected in the currency markets , '' said oanda analyst craig erlam .

documents.title: us markets welcome jobs figures
text: wall street stock indexes have opened higher after a strong set of jobs figures which showed us firms added 228,000 jobs last month .
analysts said the figures bolstered the case for a hike in interest rates next month , despite wages growing more slowly than expected .
the dow jones industrial average index rose 0.2 % to 24,258 in early trading .
the s & p 500 gained 0.3 % to 2,645 points .
and the tech-heavy nasdaq composite was up 0.7 % to 6,862 .

documents.title: no hands
text: earlier we brought you this photo of bbc business reporter theo leggett taking a self-driving car for a spin on the motorway .
in case you were worried , he did have some safety support
105kph on the motorway , look no hands !
self-driving renault # symbioz
all in the interests of research radio programme on autonomous vehicles coming soon on @ twitterid
and for those who are wondering , there was a safety driver who was able to take control at any moment ( and did so ) .

documents.title: spotify strikes deal with tencent
text: it 's the world 's most popular music streaming service - with more than 140 million active monthly users and counting - but spotify also faces questions about how it plans to stay ahead of the likes of amazon , apple and google .
the firm has gone some way towards answering that by striking a deal with chinese internet giant tencent , in which the two companies will take a stake in each other 's businesses .
it comes at a particularly interesting time for spotify , as the swedish firm , which is yet to make a profit , considers plans to list on the stock market .
spotify founder daniel ek said the tencent deal would `` allow both companies to benefit from the global growth of music streaming '' , but did n't say how much money was involved .

documents.title: eu-japan deal 'overshadowed '
text: as reported earlier , the eu struck another major agreement today - it has concluded trade negotiations with japan .
world service correspondent andrew walker explains :
for the eu the agreement is overshadowed by another set of trade negotiations that seem to be about to start - with the departing uk .
but it is an important moment .
japan represents the biggest economy with which the eu has so far signed on the dotted line .
and there could be more next week involving mexico and a group of countries in south america .
there is however no current prospect of a trade deal with the world 's two largest economies .
negotiations with the united states - known as the transatlantic trade and investment partnership - are stalled .
the eu is negotiating with china on investment not for a general free trade deal .
now , much of the eu 's negotiating capacity will be tied up with the uk .
author: Andrew Walker
World Service economics correspondent

documents.title: will the fed still raise rates ?
text: the figures on us jobs and wages are particularly important ahead of next week 's meeting of the us central bank , where policymakers are being tipped to raise interest rates .
aberdeen standard strategist luke bartholomew says wage growth of 2.5 % - below analysts ' estimates - is `` pretty awful yet again '' .
but the federal reserve - led by outgoing chair janet yellen ( - is `` almost certain to still hike next week in part because this is what they have led investors to expect '' .
`` the big question going into the end of the year is exactly what needs to be done to stir some life in wage growth .
`` trump 's tax cuts will play into the debate but they wo n't solve the riddle , '' mr bartholomew adds .

documents.title: us jobs steady after hurricanes
text: november 's us jobs report is the first clean reading since hurricanes harvey and irma , which also impacted september 's employment data .
it showed that us firms added 228,000 new jobs last month - with the unemployment rate unchanged at a 17-year low of 4.1 % .
employment gains in october were boosted by the return to work of thousands of employees who had been temporarily dislocated by the fierce storms .

documents.title: breakingus firms add jobs but wage growth disappoints
text: us companies created 228,000 new jobs in november , according to the us department of labour .
the figure is down from 244,000 in october , which was revised down from an initial estimate of 261,000 .
however , november 's count was ahead of forecasts for 200,000 new roles .
the unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.1 % .
wages grew by 2.5 % in the year to november , below expectations of a 2.7 % increase .

documents.title: eu 'concerned ' about lufthansa/air berlin deal
text: europe 's competition chief says that she has concerns about the acquisition by german airline lufthansa of routes operated by the failed air berlin .
eu competition commissioner margrethe vestager , said on friday : `` we have quite deep competition concerns because there is a risk that on some routes lufthansa becomes de facto a monopoly . ''
lufthansa offered to buy half of air berlin 's assets for around €210m ( £ 183.6m ) in october .
the german airline has offered concessions to secure the deal .
the eu competition authority is now seeking feedback from rivals and interested parties .

documents.title: power companies rapped over exit fees
text: three energy companies appear to have admitted to some fairly basic errors this morning .
npower and e.on wrongly told over 22,000 customers that they would have to pay an exit fee when they tried to switch supplier near the end of their contracts .
while utilita has had to refund some of its prepayment customers £ 3.61m , after it failed to implement the charge cap imposed by the regulator ofgem .
around 350,000 customers will get about a tenner each .
ofgem said there 's be no fines against npower and e.on , as both firms had taken steps to put things right .

documents.title: pearson turns to snap for new board member
text: education publisher pearson has appointed the chairman of snap inc , the owner snapchat , to its board to help drive its `` transformation to be a more focused , simpler digital learning company '' .

michael lynton , who was also previously chairman and chief executive of sony pictures entertainment for 10 years , will join pearson as an independent non-executive director from february next year .

documents.title: putting the dumb into dumbells
text: the ft 's `` how to spend it '' magazine is always a source of wonder .
the `` eclectibles '' section has some particularly jaw dropping items .
today it contains a pair of designer dumbbells priced at £ 800 , a backpack for £ 950 and a coffee pot for £ 5,850 .
so if you are not sure what to buy your billionaire friends for christmas - take a look .

documents.title: banks and builders spur ftse 100
text: shares in big building firms are powering the ftse 100 higher today .
the index is up 0.5 % .
berkeley group is up more than 9 % , barratt is up 4.5 % and taylor wimpey is 3 % higher .
that follows strong results from berkeley .
banks are also doing well , lloyds banking group and barclays are both up more than 3 % .
late on thursday a compromise was announced over new global banking rules that was seen as more sympathetic to the industry .
`` this appears to be a far better outcome than we and the market had feared , '' citi analyst simon nellis said in a research note .
`` this is a big positive for all european banks , which should now be able to quantify excess capital and m & a budgets in due course . ''

documents.title: will.i.am gets down to business
text: black eyed peas singer @ twitterid tells us about his plans to become the next tech innovator & says for him music is only `` for fun '' @ twitterid
watching ausi
# ionomusic

documents.title: 'gasoline on the fire ' fears over us inflation
text: at 13:30 gmt the us labor department releases its closely watched monthly employment report .
it 's expected to show the us economy created around 200,000 jobs last month .
in october 261,000 jobs were added , but that report was distorted by the return to work of thousands of staff who had been temporarily idled by hurricanes harvey and irma .
the unemployment rate is expected to be unchanged at a 17-year low of 4.1 % .
average hourly earnings will also be closely watched .
that figure is expected to rise 0.3 % in november - it was flat in october .
`` i think that in the next three to six months we will see a broader uptick in wage pressures , '' said david donabedian , chief investment officer of cibc atlantic trust .
he says that planned tax cuts could spur inflationary pressure .
`` given where we are in the economic cycle , if you throw some gasoline in the fire with fiscal stimulus , that will ultimately spark some higher inflation . ''

documents.title: buzzfeed to cut uk jobs
text: online publisher buzzfeed is planning to cut nearly a third of its staff in the uk .
buzzfeed has already announced proposals to axe 100 jobs in the us and on thursday it told staff in london 45 positions could be cut from its editorial and commercial operations .

documents.title: it 's complicated
text: the pound is flat on the dollar at $ 1.34750 but is up 0.30 % on the euro at €1.14790 .
karen briggs , head of brexit at accountancy firm kpmg , says : `` we are now entering a period that will be a lot more complicated .
the irish border issue showed how fragile brexit discussions can be and now negotiation failure could happen at the end of the talks rather than at the start .
that 's why companies are planning for a no deal scenario and some are already making investment decisions they ca n't reverse . ''
she adds : we continue to urge our clients to stress test their logistics network , supply chain exposure , customs approvals , working capital and customer expectations . ''

documents.title: uk manufacturing rises on car production
text: car production helped lift uk manufacturing output for the sixth consecutive month in october
manufacturing output increased 0.1 % .

ons statistician kate davies says : `` while manufacturing was relatively subdued overall in october despite record production of cars destined for export , the longer-term is one of strong growth . ''

documents.title: bitcoin : could be a wild ride to $ 100,000
text: has the sheen come off bitcoin ?
the cryptocurrency is now trading down 6.42 % at $ 15,776.55 , according to coindesk .
`` if there are any kind of hiccups , we could easily see a scenario where it falls back by 50 % , '' says kay van-petersen , macro and crypto-strategist with saxo bank .
however , he says that he still expects the currency to keep rising in the long term , predicting its value would hit $ 50,000 to $ 100,000 within 18 months .

documents.title: uk building output contracts - but new orders rise
text: activity in the uk construction sector shrank for the six-month in a row - registering a 1.4 % fall in output in october , according to the office for national statistics .
however there was evidence of strong new orders in infrastructure , mostly due to the hs2 rail project .
housing new orders also grew in the third quarter of 2017 .

documents.title: breakinguk trade deficit in goods widens
text: the uk 's trade deficit in goods widened slightly to £ 10.7bn in october from £ 10.4bn the previous month , according to the office for national statistics .
however , the overall trade deficit , including services was £ 1.4bn .

documents.title: japanese shares lead gains in asia
text: shares in tokyo zoomed higher on friday as a softer yen and strong economic figures buoyed investors .
the benchmark nikkei 225 index closed up 1.4 % .
data out friday showed japan sealed its longest stretch of economic growth in more than two decades , helped by a rise in business investment .
the upbeat mood spread across asia .
hong kong 's hang seng index put on 1.2 % .
australia 's s & p/asx 200 index added 0.3 % .
south korea 's kospi edged 0.1 % higher .

documents.title: ftse shrugs off brexit progress
text: despite all the fanfare about a breakthrough deal in brexit talks , the ftse 100 index barely moved on friday , rising just 0.06 % in early trading .
shares in berkeley group , the uk housebuilder , soared by 7.6 % to the top of the blue chip risers after it upgraded its pre-tax profit outlook for the year and reported soaring interim figures .
south african private hospital operator mediclinic international led the fallers on , with its shares down 1.5 % .
mediclinic 's stock had made a small recovery in recent days since its shares fell after pulling out of talks to take control of spire healthcare .
the ftse 250 is up 0.25 % , led by homeware retailer dunelem whose shares are ahead 5.5 % .

documents.title: pound dines out on 'brussels fudge '
text: the pound has crossed €1.15 against the euro , hitting its highest level since early june .
it 's up by almost one and a quarter euro cents this morning .
against the dollar it 's trading up $ 1.35 up by three quarters of a cent .
`` the brussels fudge that may and juncker have served up this morning has gone down a treat for sterling .
the pound is trading up against almost all major partners , and has reached a six month high against the euro , '' said ranko berich , head of market analysis at monex europe .

`` regardless of any future difficulties , for now the news is very positive , and next week 's leaders ' summit will conclude in celebrations , which the pound has already kicked off this morning , '' he said .

documents.title: top christmas tip from nigella lawson
text: nigella lawson 's secret to a successful christmas lunch ?
`` you need a human shield , '' she says the celebrity cook .
`` you need to have someone , or some people there , that your family do n't know well enough to behave badly in front of . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: gove : 'we can do much better than canada '
text: environment secretary michael gove tells the today programme that he 's `` optimistic and confident '' that the prime minister can secure a `` comprehensive and deep '' free trade agreement .
`` we can do something much better than canada , '' he says .
he points out that canada 's deal does not cover financial services .
he also says : `` it seems clear now we will have a two-year transition period . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: berkeley results to hit peak
text: the berkeley group says that its full-year results will be a peak for the uk housebuilder `` before returning to more normal returns in 2018/19 '' .
the company reported a 35.8 % rise in pre-tax profits to £ 533.3m for the six months to october on revenue 13.7 % higher at £ 1.6bn .
berkeley sold 2,117 homes in the interim period an average price of £ 719,000 , compared to £ 655,000 last year .
its pre-tax profit guidance has now been upgraded to £ 3.3bn from £ 3bn .

however , chief executive rob perrins says : `` there remains good underlying demand for property in london and the south east , but the combination of uncertain uk economic and political outlook and high property taxation continues to mean customers are more circumspect and inevitably purchasing later in the development cycle . ''

documents.title: breaking up is hard to do
text: president of the european council donald tusk says that the next stage of brexit talks needs to start immediately and that the uk must provide clarity on its vision for the future trading relationship
`` we all know breaking up is hard , but breaking up and building a new relationship is harder '' - donald tusk , european council president on # brexit progress

documents.title: now for the hard work
text: the cbi 's president paul drechsler says : `` history shows that trade negotiations are the toughest things that you can engage in . ''
he says : `` so for the government , we need absolute backing and support for the leaders of that negotiation , our prime minster and her team .
[ we need ] total focus , commitment and determination to be successful . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: china 's exports hit 8-month high
text: china 's exports and imports sped up last month , beating expectations .
exports in november jumped 12.3 % year-on-year , the fastest pace in 8 months , thanks in part to strong sales of electronics and high-tech goods .
that was well above analyst forecasts for a 0.5 % rise .
imports grew 17.7 % percent year-on-year for the month , official figures out friday showed , also well above expectations of 11.3 % growth .
the upbeat trade numbers may help ease concerns of slowing momentum in the world 's second largest economy .

documents.title: 'radical altering of government 's position '
text: labour mp chuka umanna , says there has been `` a radical altering of the government 's position to get to the next phase '' of brexit talks .
he his referring to the fall-back position that if there is not a deal on trade the government will maintain full alignment with the rules of the single market and customs union .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: clarity will slow brexit contingency action
text: while progress has been made on the uk 's exit from the european union , the cbi 's paul drechsler says businesses have already started triggering their contingency arrangements .
`` the fact of the matter is that companies have already started implementing contingency plans - that happened some months ago . ''
he adds : `` what clarity on transition on brexit can achieve is that people suspend further action until we know exactly where we 're heading . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: cbi : 'a step in the right direction '
text: paul drechsler , president of the confederation of british industry ( cbi ) , says today 's deal on brexit `` is an important step in the right direction '' .
what now ?
`` two things from a business point of view we 'd be particularly focused on '' , he says .
`` the first is citizens rights .
approaching the second christmas of uncertainty for nearly four million europeans , i think they will be comforted by today 's deal .
but we need unconditionally , absolute assurance that no matter what happens , citizens are going to be fine . ''
secondly , he says businesses need clarity on transition .
`` so lets let move ahead .
we can be totally confident if the team could achieve this stage of negotiations that we can do whatever we want with the right political will and determination .
and if there is unity across government , we could end up with a good deal for the uk . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: 'sufficient progress ' to advance brexit talks
text: 'sufficient progress ' to advance brexit talks

documents.title: iod : more 'comfortable ' over eu staff
text: reacting to today 's agreement in brussels , stephen martin , director general of the institute of directors , said :
the most pressing concern for uk companies has been their eu staff , who have urgently needed certainty about their future in this country .
we have grounds to hope now that our members will be able to send their employees off for the christmas break feeling more comfortable about their status here .
`` we call on the uk and eu to build on this positive momentum going into the new year .
it is overwhelmingly in the interests of both sides to begin working on our future economic relationship - particularly in order to fully address the irish question .

documents.title: hold the euphoria
text: german mep and vice-chair of the economic and monetary affairs committee markus ferber cautions against celebrating too soon about brexit .
he says : `` this is good news , but no reason to break into immediate euphoria .
`` the second phase of the negotiations will at least be as tough as the first one .
the british side should be under no illusion .
the united kingdom will become a third country like any other .
there will be no privileges or special treatment . ''
he says : `` the months to come will be about finding a sensible transition period and agreeing on the corner posts of the future relationship . ''

documents.title: all change for ba staff
text: british airways says that the new pension scheme will open on 1 april next year .
it will replace its main uk defined benefit scheme , the new airways pension scheme ( naps ) , and the main uk defined contribution scheme , the british airways retirement plan ( barp ) .
ba announced in september that it would shut naps , stating : `` since 2003 , the airline has pumped £ 3.5bn into naps , but the deficit

documents.title: breakingba to close defined benefit pension scheme
text: british airways ( ba ) has announced that it will shut its defined benefit pension scheme .
the airline , owned by international airlines group , says it will launch a flexible benefits scheme under which members can opt for cash instead of a pension .
ba says that it reached the decision `` in consultation with its trade unions and employees '' .

documents.title: pound backtracks
text: the pound has lost some of its overnight gains .
a short while ago it was trading at $ 1.3464 , it had been trading well above $ 1.35 earlier .

documents.title: a whole new world
text: bitcoin continued its wild ride overnight .
micheal jackson , a partner at mangrove capital partners and an early investor in bitcoin , says that the rise in the cryptocurrency is being fueled people on the street .
he says : `` one of our companies had half a million people join it in the last week .
this interest is causing people to buy and buy and buy . ''
but is n't this just speculative - and risky - investment ?
mr jackson says : `` you can call it a speculative investment at the moment but it is the beginning of a whole technological infrastructure which is being built today .

`` so by joining the infrastructure today you 're joining a monetary system of the future and i hope the people think that way - that they 're not just doing it to get money into their pockets in the short-term but that they want to participate in this new idea . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: brexit : integrity of uk will be maintained
text: at the news conference , prime minister theresa may is asked if there is a a special status for northern ireland .
she insists there is a way of avoiding a hard border in ireland but also maintaining the constitutional and economic integrity of the united kingdom .

documents.title: breakingnext phase of brexit talks will be opened
text: within the past few minutes , the european commission has said `` sufficient progress '' has been made in the first phase of brexit talks to move on to discussion of britain 's future relationship with the eu .
the announcement is a key moment in the negotiations on britain 's departure from the eu .

documents.title: 'be prepared '
text: despite today 's developments around brexit , seven investment management 's justin urquhart stewart says some businesses are starting to trigger their contingency plans - tentatively .

he tells the bbc 's today programme : `` what you are finding as time goes by is that more companies are saying 'yes we will start to trigger these ' but they 're not really going to spend too much money at the moment .
`` they 'll hang on a few months if they just think there 's going to be a final decision they can rely on . ''
so what 's the outlook for the pound ?
he says : `` in the past year we 've gone from $ 1.50 to $ 1.19 and here we are sort of smack in the middle of that .
be prepared - there 's going to be a lot more of that movement going on . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: the business pages
text: there are some interesting nuggets of business news in the papers today .
the guardian reports that four in 10 council homes sold under margaret thatcher 's right to buy scheme are in the hands of private landlords .
the report says tenants are paying more than twice the rent charged by local authorities .
the front page of the telegraph says that china will no longer accept recycled plastics from march .
that could be a problem for uk councils , which sends around two thirds of its plastic to the far east .
the financial times reports that one in 20 companies that have submitted data on gender pay gaps has reported numbers that are statistically improbable .

documents.title: pound set for relief rally
text: justin urquhart stewart , co-founder and head of corporate development at seven investment management , says that there will be much relief all round today as brexit talks look set to move onto trade .
what will it mean for sterling ?
`` it will be climbing for the time being if only out of the sheer relief that apparently some progress is being made , '' he says .
`` and it is no more than relief because it will then depend on the detail . ''
but he says that corporates are still worried .
`` they will invest for 12 months and not after that because they ca n't see what 's happening . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: university criticised over value for money
text: the national audit office has flagged up concerns about the information available to students when they choose a course .
it says that some english universities would be accused of mis-selling if they were regulated in a similar way to financial service providers .

`` young people are taking out substantial loans to pay for courses without much effective help and advice , and the institutions concerned are under very little competitive pressure to provide best value , '' said amyas morse , head of the national audit office .
`` if this was a regulated financial market we would be raising the question of mis-selling .
the department [ for education ] is taking action to address some of these issues , but there is a lot that remains to be done , '' she said .

documents.title: pound rises on brexit talks
text: the pound has risen by almost a cent overnight .
it 's trading at $ 1.3515 .
traders are watching carefully for brexit developments .
the prime minister is in brussels seeking a deal that could move brexit talks to the next phase - trade .
that deal was held up early this week over disagreement over how to handle the border between northern ireland and the republic .
we could hear something later this morning .
watch this space .

documents.title: good morning !
text: welcome to friday 's business live page .
we 'll be keeping an eye on the pound , it 's moving higher on hopes of progress in brexit talks .
the national audit office questions whether some university students in england are getting value for money .
plus , there 's a key piece of us economic data out later - the monthly jobs report .
author: Ben Morris
Business reporter
